results.title: Tomorrow it will be fine
results.brief_description:
A popular explanation of the way in which reports from widely separated weather stations are coordinated to produce weather maps and forecasts.
English version by H. Aisner and L. Barrache, spoken by Ken Pittendrigh.

results.title: Tomorrow is today
results.brief_description: Tells of the expanding needs of an increasing population; discusses the stresses and strains of youth and the responsibility of leadership as education, science and industry move ahead. Describes the advantages that scouting offers to a community.

results.title: Tomorrow is ours
results.creator_credit: Jehangir Bhownagary and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: The speaker was a “displaced person” who had lived for eight years with a village in India; he is meeting with the head villagers to explain what had been done in the 1951 first Five Year Plan that was now ending, of the path at “free” India was leading the people on, and the forthcoming Five Year Plan.

results.title: Tomorrow is now
results.brief_description: The work of the Post Office research laboratories in Melbourne in a brief coverage of six of the many current research projects. These are: testing of telephones, operation of the time and frequency standard, the effect and control of plume radiation on aerial systems, microwave propagation testing, experiments with optical fibres and trials conducted with a computer controlled exchange.

results.title: Tomorrow is maybe
results.creator_credit: KRMA-TV (Television station : Denver, Colo.) and Michael Halvajian
results.brief_description: Examines man’s dilemma of how to behave toward his environment. Is modern urban life, with its artificiality and ugly trappings of pollution and untrammelled usage of nature’s commodities, an instinctive protection against the alien silence and solitude of the wilderness? Narrated by Ben Aviary.

results.title: Tomorrow is another day
results.brief_description: The race for global and spacial dominance asserts itself in the form of armaments and their destructive capabilities. This animated film’s symbolic message poses a frightening problem: Is there hope for peaceful atomic applications or are nations so obsessed with destruction as a token of aggrandisement that the call for peace is merely a mushroom-cloud transparency?

results.title: Tomorrow in their hands
results.brief_description: Illustrates some of the uses of non-military aid to developing nations. Film of actual aid projects in El Salvador, Bolivia, India, Pakistan, Thailand and Ethiopia is used to show that the major objectives of US aid to these nations depends largely on self-help and cooperation in each participating country. Narrated by Jason Robards.

results.title: Tomorrow by air
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”
At the end of WWII, the British aircraft industry was faced with the problems of making a swift changeover from wartime to peacetime aircraft production. Since the end of the war, the British aviation and aircraft industry has attempted to take the lead in the production of fast planes, particularly jet planes, large freight planes, and passenger planes (eg the Brabazon, still in the process of being built when this film was made), and in the general problems of aeronautics and aviation research.

results.title: Tomorrow begins today
results.creator_credit: United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East
results.brief_description: Dealing with the refugee problem in the Middle East, including the difficulties faced by the children. As a result of armed conflict in 1948 in the Holy Land, nearly one million Arabs became refugees. This film shows the steps taken by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency to help in educating and resettling these people.
